article.description: Ron Mercer scored 15 points to lead seven players in double figures as the Bulls opened the Bill Cartwright era with a 103-80 drubbing of the Cleveland Cavaliers.

related.description: Bill Cartwright has a new title to go along with the five NBA championship rings he won as a player and an assistant coach with the Chicago Bulls. Head coach.
related.linkText: Another title for Cartwright: Bulls head coach
related.title: Cartwright to debut Saturday as Bulls coach
related.headline: Cartwright to debut Saturday as Bulls coach

article.headline: Bulls open Cartwright era with newfound energy
article.linkText: Must be the coaching: Bulls win Cartwright's debut by 23
article.story:
CHICAGO (AP) -- As Bill Cartwright walked on the court for the first time as head coach of the Chicago Bulls, a standing ovation brought a smile to his face. A few hours later as he departed the same floor Saturday night, Cartwright's smile reappeared after his team responded with one of its best efforts of the season. "The fans were terrific. I was really surprised. They gave me a nice ovation, which I appreciated. Their enthusiasm set the tone for the game," Cartwright said after the Bulls matched their highest scoring game of the season by routing the Cleveland Cavaliers 103-80. "Our guys guarded probably as well as they have all season. It's huge. It's great to win. This team I felt was ready to win," Cartwright said. Cartwright, the center on the Bulls' first three championship teams, took over as head coach Friday, three days after Tim Floyd resigned. It's a new seat on the bench, close to his old one as an assistant, but in some respects a world away. "Now you have responsibility for everything on the court," Cartwright said. "It was an emotional game. I do believe we can take things we did and use them in our next game." Using a tough in-your-face defense that Cartwright promised would be a staple of his teams, the Bulls had separate second-quarter spurts of 13-2 and 7-0 and took a 53-40 halftime lead. Then Ron Artest scored seven as Chicago broke away with a 20-6 run to start the second half to build a 25-point cushion. "It was a matter of going out and playing hard for coach Cartwright," said Ron Mercer, who led the Bulls with 15 points. "It is like you are starting over, like coming out of training camp for your first game." Cartwright's long 16-year career as a player has an impact on his players. He has five championship rings, three as a player, two as an assistant. "Everybody has seen coach on TV, playing with Michael Jordan. He's a champion," said Artest, explaining the Bulls' defensive energy that helped them snap an eight-game losing streak. "Now we can go home and sleep without having losing on our mind," Artest added. Cavaliers coach John Lucas, whose team was playing its second game in two nights, said coaching changes usually spark a team for a period of time. "People get energy for one or two weeks, then we'll see," he said. "The change is good but the next change is with the players. "We knew we were walking into the lion's den with a new coach coming in and with us playing a tough, emotional game last night." Artest finished with 14 points as the Bulls shared the ball -- another Cartwright philosophy -- and had seven players in double figures. Chris Mihm scored 13 points to lead the Cavaliers. As he got a feel for the desk chair in Floyd's old office before the game, the 7-foot-1 Cartwright said he had no jitters and was a little bothered that he didn't. "I feel OK because we have played this team before," he said. But in that game 11 days ago when he was still an assistant, the Cavaliers won by 18.

Game notes
Cartwright said he'd talked with relatives and his high school and college coaches since getting the job Friday. But he hadn't heard from Lakers coach Phil Jackson, for whom he played and was an assistant in Chicago. Cartwright said he might call Jackson. "I may need some meditation," he said. ... One of Cartwright's first moves was to put Charles Oakley back as a starter in place of Marcus Fizer. Fizer scored 11 as a reserve. ... Mihm, a former draft pick of the Bulls, fouled out with 2:37 left in the third quarter. ... Chicago's 23-point margin of victory was the highest for any Bulls coach in his debut.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
